title: Did Cinder really need that nerf?
body:
Out of all the things that needed nerfs this patch, this was probably the last thing that needed to be nerfed, especially after the other tank nerfs. Fact of the matter is, out of the top 20 junglers being played right now, 3 are Cinder users. And even of those, champions like Hec could go either way. It just seems unnecessary when Devour is by far dominating the top junglers right now, and is extremely gold effective. 

While I'm sure this would have been necessary when Tank junglers were dominating the Rift, after the collective nerfs to most of their items which also gives a buff to other AD users, and the subsequent buffs to champs like Lee, it seems like the tanks are going to be more and more fazed out. 

Maybe I'm off base here, but as someone who enjoys playing champions like this, it seems like kind of a middle finger to them, and honestly I'm not sure why. They were in a decent spot, and if anything, some of the devour users needed to be toned down.

replies.body:
The Cinderhulk changes read as much more a nerf than they really are. They may actually be a buff even, early game power is typically more valuable than late game power.

The item will be better when you purchase it by a pretty meaningful amount. Though the scaling passive is reduced, the stronger early values are likely to have some trickle down effect into the later stages of the game, since more power early game converts to more gold/experience acquisition on average.
100 health will not matter nearly as much as you think it does.

It's actually 85 HP, once you factor in the passive.

300 + 75 vs 400 + 60

By the time you have 1000 bonus HP before the percent bonus--pretty much your second HP item, considering runes/masteries--old Cinderhulk is better.

That was my feeling. It wasn't even that much of an early/mid game buff, as 100 hp, or as you said 85, is achieved after about the second tank item. Of everything out there right now jungle wise, Cinder was the last thing needing nerfs, ESPECIALLY after the other tank item nerfs. I guess I better be learning other junglers now...
85 health, then. That matters even less.

The 100 health you gain on purchase to bolster your horrible early game will matter a lot more than the ~500 health you lose on your full build later on.

Every little bit counts when your early game is weak, and that 100 extra health is that little bit that counts in the early game.

But when your late game is strong, the 500 health that you MIGHT lose (either having the game end before reaching a build where this matters or having a build that grants around the same amount of HP as before) isn't as relevant because you are already going to be really strong at that stage in the game.

Think of it like Nasus stacks. In the early game, Nasus getting one Siphoning Strike stack when he has none is a big deal, but later on, Nasus getting a Siphoning Strike stack when he already has 600 doesn't matter so much, and Cinderhulk is the same exact deal.
100 health is basically an auto or two, or a single spell. Late game, 500 health is a couple of autos from an ADC, or one big crit, and maybe two spells.

You actually never lose out on 500 Health late-game, it's pretty much impossible. For example, if your full build was Randuins (500 HP) + Cleaver (400 HP) + Glory (500 HP) + Warmog's (800 HP) + Cinderhulk, and you have HP masteries, then you will only get 145 less HP from new Cinderhulk compared to the old one.

500 health was a severe overestimation on my part. You need 1000 bonus health to break even, then for every 1000 health you lose 100 bonus health from Cinderhulk, meaning that you need 6000 bonus health to lose out on that much health. For reference, the highest health build you can get with Cinderhulk (Cinderhulk + 5 Warmogs armors) gets to 4400 bonus HP, losing you 340 HP from a terrible build. That's not counting Health masteries, but I don't think you can get past 5000 bonus health, and if you can you are going to get completely hammered by % health damage on Bork, especially considering you don't have resistances.

You lose between 100-200 health on a reasonable full build, and 100-200 health in the late game matters as much as the health you gain on purchase.

>100-200 health in the late game matters as much as the health you gain on purchase.

Really have to disagree there. 100 health early on is going to be a significantly larger percentage of your total health at that time than the roughly 150 health will be later. Any single instance of a flat value like health is going to matter more in the early game than it will in the late game because it represents a greater percentage of your total power at the time that you get it. It is important that the late game stats you lose are higher than the early game stats you gain, but that inky really serves to equalize the value. 100 health early in exchange for 150ish health late is pretty fair as far as I'm concerned.
Cho'gath could do it, but you're right that it's a horrible build.

Don't forget resistances.

Early-game, you have to try to build more than 50 Armor or MR. Come late-game, most Cinder builders have a natural 80+ Armor and 50+ MR, without accounting for any bonuses. With 150 Armor, that 500 HP blocks 1250 physical damage.
Early game for a tanking character health is more valuable than armor or MR so this isn't a bad as people make it.

That depends *a lot* on your champion's base resistances.

Also, **wasn't I just stating that the problem is late-game?**

So... less HP on full build plus less armour from armour items isn't a large buff? It's a double hit to jungle tanks...

Wasn't cinderhulk originally intended to allow tanks to scale into the late-game a little better?

Look, I really respect you and everyone on the boards is almost always excited to hear you speak (figuratively speaking) on hot topics, but I honestly feel like this is sugarcoating the issue. 100 health (and as some people have already done some quick math, it's 85 effective health altogether with the passives) is not going to do much. That's basically an extra autoattack early game, in exchange for hundreds of health lost especially coupled with the recent tank items nerf that's coming. 

I mean, imagine changing infinity edge to give 85 AD but its passive was changed to 220%. Or nerfing Bork to deal 4%hp but giving it 30 attack damage. People would still buy it, it just wouldn't be as tough. It wouldn't feel good anymore.

Honestly, I wouldn't mind so much if the damage of cinderhulk was buffed to compensate to make it a stronger mid-game item, but otherwise sunfire cape is starting to look better overall. You might as well give cinderhulk a different build path and passive so people can build sunfire cape for a stronger and better midgame power spike :/

I just don't understand the logic behind the recent nerfs, buffs, and what is being changed. On devour the riot team commented that they would rather go and nerf champions individually rather than alter the item itself (which is kinda bad because if a champ was in a healthy state in lane this really forces them into the jungle) but then you nerf cinderhulk. Lets be realistic, Junglers will rush their jungle item 9 times out of 10. reducing the price isn't an inherent buff, the power spike is acquiring the preliminary jungle item, not the enchantment. the players ability to clear camps and make successful ganks will determine the final jungle item time in game. 

The play style with jungler vs jungler. Cinderhulk is encouraging ganks. you have you jungle item, you are in a fairly healthy competitive spot in the game, time to try to cause some disruption in lane. Devour you are much more focused on getting your stacks. You are more focused on acquiring your stacks then you are of winnning lanes. Simply because once you have your stacks, the power spike is huge. very rarely are junglers meeting in jungle.

Isn't this a buff to bruiser/fighter junglers (Lee, Elise, Ekko, Nid, Rek) and a straight nerf to the tank junglers for which the item was originally made (Naut, Sej, Zac)?
